tags: this is completely unrelated but i want gemma chan to step on my neck
summary:
Villanelle: Ugh, this date is so boring
Eve: This isn’t a date. I said I was going to the store.
Villanelle: Then why did you...
body:
Villanelle: Ugh, this date is so boring

Eve: This isn’t a date. I said I was going to the store.

Villanelle: Then why did you invite me?

Eve: I specifically said, “Don’t come with me” and you said “fuck you, Eve. I’ll do whatever I want!” and walked with me to the store

summary:
Just finished binge watching Killing Eve and.... Wow! 
It was completely unexpected, refreshing, and downright intriguing! I...
body:
Just finished binge watching Killing Eve and…. Wow!

It was completely unexpected, refreshing, and downright intriguing! I can’t wait for the next season! *fangirl squeals*

Not to spoil this for anyone but the actress who plays Villanelle is so good (not to downplay Sandra Oh- thank God she left Grey’s, they did not utilize her to her full potential at all!)..but yes, I don’t know the actresses name but she plays an amazing psychopath. That ending scene where (spoiler alert)

- Eve stabbed her in the stomach and they tearfully locked eyes with Villanelle saying,

“I really liked you..”

Was just beautiful! I honestly felt sad for Villanelle, her voice was filled with so much hurt and confusion. Hell, I had to seriously reevaluate how I felt about the entire show with that one scene. Seriously, in that instant I honestly was rooting for Eve to just run off with her and live happily ever after. Forget her husband, forget her job, just say fuck it to all and live in dreamy Paris with a certified psychotic lesbian (or bisexual?) assassin… *sighs* But no, that isn’t how things ended and I will be a certified bitch for spoiling such goodness for anyone who reads this (after ignoring the spoiler alert) and is interested enough to watch the series. Now back to the rest!

(spoiler ends)

Aside from the storyline, the show itself has damn good music, is filmed cinematicly, and the acting is superb from the entire cast. I can’t believe I missed out on such a great series! On a different note, this kind of reminds me of another BBC favorite of mine, Orphan Black, with its shady government plots and never ending plot twist. Tatiana Masaley (apologies if spelled wrong) was epic in there!

Anyway, if you haven’t seen it, go see it! Killing Eve is amazing..!

blog.name: garland-on-thy-brow
blog.title: the brooding drummer who steals fans' hearts
blog.description:
Gene | lesbian | 23 | they/them, she/her, occasionally he/him.

Main topic: Late Roman Republic and its interpretations in fiction. Won't shut up about the portrait of Sempronia. Won't shut up about Bridge Theatre Julius Caesar.

Anthony J. Crowley wrote Shakespeare's Julius Caesar. Veva Blanc is alchemical. Symbrock is Brutecass. Killing Eve is EVErything. Rachel Weisz should play Philippa Eilhart.

[AO3]. Tags, about.

summary: Killing Eve ep. 1  Elisabetta Sirani, Portia Wounding Her Leg  In the painting, Porcia's voluntary wound is a show of strength,...
caption:
• Killing Eve ep. 1
  • Elisabetta Sirani, Portia Wounding Her Leg

In the painting, Porcia’s voluntary wound is a show of strength, intended to set her apart from other women (seen in the background). In the frame, the place of those women is taken by the dead man, Villanelle’s victim. We may conclude it is him who Eve separates herself from (paradoxically, by recreating the wound he died from). Now, the man’s fatal mistake was not paying attention to Villanelle, and this is the mistake Eve is not making.

reblog.comment:

summary: “So, Eve. Good news, or not-so-good news?” “Not-so-good news first, I think.” “OK. Well, you understand the basics of the game....
body:
“So, Eve. Good news, or not-so-good news?”
“Not-so-good news first, I think.”
“OK. Well, you understand the basics of the game. You learnt as a child?”
“My parents both played, yes.”
“And you like, very much, to win.”
Eve meets his gaze. “Is it that obvious?”
“To others, maybe not. You like to play the myszka, the mouse. But I see
the fox.”

(Luke Jennings, Codename Villanelle)

And then he said — let me see if I can quote him word for word: “You have delusions of piety, delusions about your own nature. I’m a wiry fox and my nose is still keen, and in this room I smell another fox. I tell you this, Cicero: The path you’ve chosen in life leads to only one place in the end, and that is the place where I stand. Your path may not take you as far, but it will take you nowhere else. Look at Lucius Sulla and see your mirror.”

(Steven Saylor, Catilina’s Riddle)

Ceterum censeo Sandra Oh and Jodie Comer should play Cicero and Catilina.
